comments.commentBody: Tomorrow's game counts for the Yankees but its not a game in which a statement has to be made. We have to work hard, but we are not in terrible straits.

Happy debut Jill. Hope you are always on the "on" ramp. Nice puzzle!
To Wags 2. There is a AAAA battery. I had a slim laser pointer which required them. Very expensive.

The country and the world lack the energy menu? Who started that rumor? Here's the menu:

Coal and oil: Diarrhea and vomiting, along with adding vast additional amounts of greenhouse gases to an atmosphere already choking from them. Result: major ecological and human disruptions, with possible catastrophic runaway impacts.

Solar, wind, and geothermal: Abundant, simple, non polluting, and necessary to slow and reverse the dangerous trend of rapidly increasing temperatures.

Most Americans have figured this out, and far higher percentages of Europeans and South Americans have done likewise.

The problem is systemic corruption of political activity and media communication, at the behest of greed crazed, sociopathic, and dirty sunset industries, along with their enablers in the banks and investment firms. The positive alternatives are already on the "menu". It's no more complicated than that.

Data Disproves Accelerated Global Warming of the IPCC

1) Observed global warming rate of 0.03 deg C per decade is about 1/6th the IPCC projections of 0.2 deg C per decade.

IPCC Projections: http://www.ipcc.ch...

Observed Trends: http://www.woodfortrees.org...

2) After human emission of CO2 for 60 years, the global warming rate from 1970 to 2000 of 0.16 deg C per decade is nearly identical to the value of 0.15 deg C per decade from 1910 to 1940.
http://www.woodfortrees.org...

3) The pattern of global mean temperature is cyclic with cooling from 1880 to 1910, warming from 1910 to 1940, cooling from 1940 to 1970 & warming from 1970 to 2000. From this pattern, a cooling from 2000 to 2030 is predicted. Data does not show the accelerated warming of the IPCC.

http://www.woodfortrees.org...

Why is it necessary to force everyone to contribute to the perceived emergencies regarding the energy or the climate?  As citizens you are free to spend your entire waking day improving wind, solar, insulation technology, anything.  Stealing the from hard working Americans (I know you hate that word) to fight the manufactured demons of the IPCC, is an injustice.  Feel free to let your majority (as long as it lasts) sacrifice their modern lifestyle to save planet earth.  Our great grandchildren will congratulate (or laugh) at your great grandchildren in 2100.

And THIS From The Media?

When these sorts of partly correct thoughts, that capture some percentage of the story but miss the larger percentage, or misunderstand it, and that are unwisely assumed to lead to largely incorrect choices, are conveyed by the media (of all folks!), what then? Where does one begin to disentangle this sort of stuff? Does one begin by discussing self-fulfilling prophesies? Or, does one start by discussing the naturalistic fallacy? Or, does one jump right to the point (again, for the fiftieth time) of the media's own central role in the problem?

Really, where does one begin?

All I can say is that most of the media -- before uttering another word, or writing one -- should examine their own role, and themselves.

Sorry for that bluntness. History will prove it to be correct.

Sigh,

Jeff
What a joke.

I think it will be incredibly interesting to see how the location services change over time - especially when you are now starting to see the early attempts to monetise.

Surely this is another area that can be paired with a service like TopGuest (or other similar ideas) where you can link location to loyalty and get rewarded in some meaningful way. You would also think that Yelp would be able to offer something interesting as well.
This is fantastic.  The Please Rob Me website will have even more information on all those empty houses out there.

Cool!  Twitter just keeps getting better and better.  It truly is my fav of the social media sites out there, and I love the fact I can search by location.  Of course now I know why the fail whale is sailing at Twitter at this moment.  It seems every time a major announcement about Twitter comes out it goes down.  In fact I wouldn't even be at this blog right now.  I would be at Twitter chatting with all my book-addict fans and readers.  As we say in Twitterland, "Fail Whale GO AWAY!"  *falls over laughing*  Okay, I'm of to check Twitter again...

"political statement", that's a fool's statement from someone who has drunk the koolaid. Safari is completely open to the internet, if you want your porn, go to a web browser. Apps are sold in Apple's store. Every store has the right to decide what they want to sell. Noone said Apple's AppStore would be the Wild Wild West where anything goes. Can you buy porn at WalMart? No, it's their store and they decide what they want to sell, and noone talks about censorship and noone makes a political statement about it. How is Apple's AppStore different from WalMart? It's not. The people who complain about what gets sold in the AppStore are hypocrites if they aren't boycotting stores like WalMart or Target or Macy's or any other store that doesn't sell what they want. They are too lame to actually think thru their "political statement" to realize how ludicrous it is.

Terrific interview. Fred's point about fearlessness in young tech companies is a huge success factor. Reckless conviction at the start of things can end up looking like market-changing wisdom in hindsight, once something succeeds. No matter what you call it, it's hard to do something big based on solving well understood challenges incrementally.

Jon Goldman
www.Qlipso.com

Dear New York Times kill the RSS feed, actually kill your web site, Problem Solved! you are welcome.

Just put adds in the RSS articles and you can profit there, if you sue for that then sue Google, HP, Dell and all PC makers they charge for a device that allows us to see your free RSS, also the ISP's they chargee us for the network that allows us to download your free RSS.

There are times when someone inside the company has to stop the DAMN lawyers, they only care in lawsuits, after all is their job, they don't think in PR marketing and customers.

While it may be that 98% of users use less than 2 GB of data per month on average,  you don't get charged based on your average usage.  If you exceed 2GB some months and not others, your average may be below 2 GB, but you still pay extra for every month that you exceed it.  This seems like misleading AT&T advertising which is just getting parroted by the Times.

This is nothing new at all. Since the wii was introduced there have been peripheral "add-ons" that only make sense for the creative minds of young children. They actually frustrate the playing experience turning the controller into an unwieldy object too big for its own good. This solves no problem but manages to create more.
The term "halting progress" really doesn't fit.  Where's the evidence of progress?  Halting the war would be progress.

Well, there isn't much of a choice for Obama here:

pull out before there is an semblance of stability, if there were another attack against the US or if the Taliban returned to power, he'd be eaten alive, not to mention the political fallout whenever there is an election: Bush started this whole "surge" strategy, he produced some kind of progress (though we all know it's still far from over and far from definitive, but let give credit where credit is due, Bush had something to show for with regard to Iraq during the last two years of his tenure), Obama emulated him but failed to produce result, do you think how damaging it would be in a campaign?

stay the course, there probably will be some backlashes among Democrats, but now with the economy in a ditch, I don't think most people are really that concerned with a war that has been going on for years and though casualty still happening, there is no eye-popping of US casualties.

If by the time his time comes up, there is still no discernible "progress", I have no doubt obama will opt for a longer stay. That's just how game in politics is played.

It was always an idiotic idea to set a definite timetable to begin withdrawing from Afghanistan. Didn't President Obama learn anything from Iraq? Obama has spent an inordinate amount of time reassuring our allies in NATO and (especially) Pakistan that the US intends to stay the course. Pakistan has little incentive to cut ties with the Taliban if the US withdraws since they consider Karzai much too friendly toward India.

In addition, with the unrealistic expectations (18 month surge) and the announcement of a withdrawal date, he emboldened the Taliban to hold out until the US withdraws from Afghanistan. I credit Obama for increasing the drone attacks which have been particularly effective, but it was a mistake of epic proportions to announce a date to begin withdrawal of US troops (just to please his base of support).

Obama must change his plans if progress continues to move at such a slow pace (kandahar being the key), and Obama must listen to General Petraeus.
Well, surprise, surprise! This should give us time to establish control of the raw material "recently" discovered and deliver it to the corporations. More war for money.
Surprise, surprise. Has nothing to do with the news from the USGS...
Time to leave.

What is this? Is the Times being played by the Pentagon? First, there is an article about a new Pentagon-supported survey which shows Afghanistan has up to a trillion dollars in mineral wealth, and that the Chinese are after it, or, even worse, that the Taliban might get it. By mid-day, everyone is pointing out that the presence of mineral wealth in that country is old news. So, why the breaking story?
By the end of the SAME DAY, here is an article in which military officials express serious doubts about the timetable for withdrawal. You think that's a coincidence? This is propaganda. The military-industrial complex does not want to leave that country until it has appropriated those resources. That's what this war has become about, just like the war in Iraq. It's not about democracy, human rights, women's rights or even national security. It's not even about defeating Islamic extremists. The military knows that force only creates more terrorists. It's not about 'victory'. They know there is no winning an all-out war in Afghanistan and Pakistan. What they want is endless war. War that lasts long enough to allow them to strong-arm the future political leadership in Afghanistan, which may not include Karzai, into allowing U.S. companies to develop the country's resources. The same thing Russia wanted. The same thing Halliburton wanted in Iraq.

Surprise, surprise! The government gets the NYT to announce the "newfound" mineral deposits in Afghanistan, and the next day the NYT announces that the war is going to be just a bit longer than expected because of unforeseeable circustances, and blah, blah, blah. What a fortuitous coincidence!

PS. What ever happened to the press being the watchdog of the government? Puppet. Watchdog. They're not one in the same.

This is not a situation in which a new strategy can be pulled out of a hat like the 2007 Surge in Iraq. All of the options are on the table and have been debated publicly. Is there really any indication that a favorable outcome is available fighting a hearts and minds campaign when the local populations know that we will not stay and that those who collaborate with us will eventually be punished by the Taliban?

At the age of 53, I am becoming resigned to the fact this Country will always be at war until I depart.  It will ultimately lead to our Country's demise, but unfortunately, all of those who enacted these failed policies will have departed and the innocent victims (our grandchildren and great grandchildren) will be left to suffer.  We had so much potential that we just squandered.  Disgusting!
